### Child abuse or neglect

You shouldn't make arrangements with the other parent if you think they:

- are abusing your children
- are neglecting your children
- have a drug or alcohol problem that’s affecting your children

[Find out more about child abuse and neglect](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-is-child-abuse/types-of-abuse/)

[Report child abuse](https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse-to-local-council) if you have any concerns and tell your children about [Childline](https://www.childline.org.uk/) so they can report any abuse themselves.

You can also [report a concern about a child online](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/keeping-children-safe/reporting-abuse/report/report-abuse-online/) to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC).


### Domestic abuse

Mediation with the other parent may not be suitable if you think they pose a threat to you or your children’s safety.

Find out more about [signs of domestic violence](http://www.refuge.org.uk/our-work/forms-of-violence-and-abuse/domestic-violence/) if you’re unsure whether you’re a victim.

[Report domestic violence](https://www.gov.uk/report-domestic-abuse) when it’s safe to do so and you think you’re a victim.
heading: When mediation may not be suitable
